name: Rina Kapoor
description: Rina is a 29-year-old data analyst in Portland who channels her analytical mindset into a meticulous, creative photography practice. She shoots primarily with a mid-range mirrorless APS-C camera, favoring prime lenses for street, environmental portraits, and misty forest scenes on weekend hikes. Curious and methodical, she plans shoots around golden and blue hours, keeps a running list of techniques to master (long exposures, off-camera flash, focus stacking), and evaluates her progress by reviewing EXIF data and contact sheets. She’s budget-conscious but gear-savvy: researches accessories obsessively, buys quality secondhand, and sells older kit to fund upgrades. Rina enjoys the craft behind the image—calibrating her monitor, building custom Lightroom presets, and comparing color renditions across lenses—yet she prioritizes story and composition over specs. Community matters to her: she joins local photowalks, participates in respectful critique circles, and volunteers at nonprofit events to sharpen real-world skills. Long-term, she aims to assemble a cohesive photo essay on urban renewal and green spaces, culminating in a small gallery show or zine series. Challenges include avoiding accessory decision paralysis, organizing her growing gear and prints, and balancing post-processing time with a full-time job. She values ethical practice (model releases, leave-no-trace on trails) and enjoys mentoring newer hobbyists with practical, repeatable exercises.
example_behaviours: Schedules sunrise and blue-hour shoots twice weekly and logs camera settings and results
Keeps a Trello board of techniques to learn and pairs each with a mini-assignment
Watches gear and technique channels, then A/B tests settings in controlled backyard scenes
Adapts vintage manual lenses and practices zone focusing on photowalks
Builds and refines Lightroom presets, keeping before/after comparisons in a reference catalog
Participates in monthly critique nights with a two-minute-per-image feedback format
3D-prints simple accessories like lens hoods and gel holders for speedlights
Maintains a gear spreadsheet tracking costs, resale value, and upgrade priorities
Volunteers as a photographer for local community events to practice candid work
Prints quarterly photo zines and trades them at local art markets
Performs routine maintenance—sensor swabs, firmware updates, and backup checks every Sunday
Leads occasional city “composition scavenger hunts” for beginners to practice framing
